factoid: Rostóv watched the colonel closely.
Rostóv looked for confirmation of his conjecture in the colonel's face.
The colonel did not glance at Rostóv.
The colonel looked solemn and stern when at the front.
The colonel shouted "Look sharp! Look sharp!" to the hussars.
The hussars' sabers caught in the bridles.
The hussars' spurs jingled.
The hussars hastily dismounted.
The hussars did not know what to do.
The men were crossing themselves.
Rostóv no longer looked at the colonel.
Rostóv had no time.
Rostóv was afraid of falling behind the hussars.
Rostóv's heart stood still.
Rostóv's hand trembled as he gave his horse into an orderly's charge.
Rostóv felt the blood rush to his heart with a thud.
Denísov rode past Rostóv, leaning back and shouting something.
Rostóv saw the hussars running all around him.
The hussars' spurs were catching.
The hussars' sabers were clattering.
Someone shouted "Stretchers!" behind Rostóv.
Rostóv did not think about the meaning of the call for stretchers.
Rostóv ran on trying only to be ahead of the others.
Rostóv stumbled on sticky, trodden mud at the bridge.
Rostóv fell on his hands at the bridge.
The others outstripped Rostóv.
The colonel had a triumphant, cheerful face.
Rostóv wiped his muddy hands on his breeches.
Rostóv looked at the colonel.
Rostóv was about to run on, thinking that the farther he went to the front the better.
Bogdánich shouted to Rostóv: "Who’s that running on the middle of the bridge? To the right! Come back, Cadet!"
Bogdánich turned to Denísov.
Bogdánich told Denísov: "Why run risks, Captain? You should dismount."
Denísov answered: "Oh, every bullet has its billet."
Denísov turned in his saddle.
Nesvítski, Zherkóv, and the officer of the suite were standing together out of range of the shots.
They were watching a small group of men with yellow shakos, dark-green jackets braided with cord, and blue riding breeches swarming near the bridge.
They were watching blue uniforms and groups with horses approaching from the opposite side.
The blue uniforms were easily recognizable as artillery.
The men on the high ground above the bridge were watching the bridge and the hussars in the bright evening light.
The men on the high ground above the bridge were watching blue tunics advancing from the other side with bayonets and guns.
The men on the high ground above the bridge asked questions about burning the bridge, who would get there first, and whether the French would get within grapeshot range and wipe them out.
Nesvítski said: "Ugh. The hussars will get it hot!"
Nesvítski said: "They are within grapeshot range now."
The officer of the suite said: "He shouldn’t have taken so many men."
Nesvítski answered: "True enough. Two smart fellows could have done the job just as well."

Zherkóv said: "Ah, your excellency! How you look at things! Send two men? And who then would give us the Vladimir medal and ribbon? But now, even if they do get peppered, the squadron may be recommended for honors and he may get a ribbon. Our Bogdánich knows how things are done."
The officer of the suite said: "That’s grapeshot."
The officer of the suite pointed to the French guns.
The limbers of the French guns were being detached and hurriedly removed.
On the French side, a cloud of smoke appeared.
A second cloud of smoke appeared almost simultaneously.
A third cloud of smoke appeared almost simultaneously.
At the moment when the first report was heard, a fourth cloud of smoke was seen.
Then two reports came one after another, and a third.
Nesvítski groaned: "Oh! Oh!"
Nesvítski seized the officer of the suite by the arm.
Nesvítski said: "Look! A man has fallen! Fallen, fallen!"
Nesvítski said: "Two, I think."
The colonel had ridden ahead and pulled up his horse near the bridge.
